summary: The memorandum details the evaluation of an open sight hood for the 7.62mm Belgium (FAL) Rifle, developed under the President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Act of 1992. It covers performance tests under various lighting conditions, comparisons with other sighting systems, and the use of underloaded ammunition with cream of wheat filler. The document also addresses the sight hood's compatibility with different rifles and its operational use, alongside findings on sound levels and silencer clogging concerns.
key_findings: The open sight hood was developed as a simpler alternative to the Modified Williams peep sight, which was deemed unsatisfactory.
Familiarization was required for the open sight hood, which was more challenging for maintaining uniform vertical grouping than the peep sight.
Underloaded ammunition with cream of wheat filler performed consistently without issues from soft annealed cases.
The sight hood proved beneficial in poor lighting, though a scope was better with some illumination.
Sound from the mechanism and fired rounds could be detected up to 275 yards away by an attentive listener.
Cream of wheat filler was found to partially clog the silencer, leaving residue post-tests.
Fit problems with the sight hood on various rifles were resolved by providing small files for adjustments.
A sniper scope for the 7.62mm Belgium (FAL) Rifle was identified as available in the Agency supply system.
